Exciting news! In partnership with the Milken Center for Advancing the American Dream, we’re thrilled to launch The American Dream Academy, a new, free, online program designed to help Americans gain the skills needed to pursue in-demand jobs or continue their education. Enroll in the American Dream Academy today.  Through the program, you will:  - Gain access to a curated selection of courses on the Coursera platform designed to help you develop job-ready skills for in-demand careers. - Earn a credential that can prepare you for jobs in high-growth fields.  - Have the opportunity to earn college credit for specific eligible programs.  - Assess your strengths, define your purpose, and set goals. - Earn access to job boards with over 150 employer partners if you complete a Google or Meta Professional Certificate. - Virtually connect with a community of peer learners through webinars and virtual experiences to build tools that can help you succeed at work or continue your education.  Enroll in The American Dream Academy today: https://bit.ly/3MCJ4fv

Groundbreaking leaders such as former First Lady Michelle Obama, National Youth Poet Laureate Amanda Gorman, and tennis superstar Serena Williams, know firsthand the importance of walking your own path and resisting the imposition of limits. When there was no narrative big enough to contain their ambitions, they wrote a bigger story.  The same can be said of women leaders across all sectors of business and society—everywhere you look, there are stories of challenge and success; opportunity and ambition; trial and triumph.   In this inspiring article, women in a wide range of leadership positions share their tips and advice on how to grow your skills, achieve your goals, and build the career you deserve. https://bit.ly/3C8OQ3x  #WomensHistoryMonth

Career journeys can take some pretty interesting turns sometimes. Take Alyssa. She was a TV host for a year before enrolling at the New York Film Academy. She got hired as a video editor, but then the pandemic hit. When she lost her job, she had to rethink her plans. Alyssa loved connecting with people and building relationships, and she’d also always had an interest in tech. Could she combine the two? Her research took her to Coursera, where she discovered the Salesforce Sales Development Representative Professional Certificate program. She enrolled and embarked on a new leg of her journey. Today, she’s using her new skills as an Internal Communication Specialist at a tech start-up—proof that success doesn’t always come in straight lines. Learn more about Alyssa’s journey here: https://bit.ly/3eUfyCm

We all start from somewhere, and it can feel nice to celebrate the milestones along the way––no matter your goal. Share below where you started and how it’s going now so all of us can cheer you on, too!  We’ll go first:  Where it started: It’s 2012 and two Stanford professors Daphne Koller and Andrew Ng launched a free Machine Learning course on a platform called Coursera  How it’s going: It’s 2021 and 87 million learners, 100+ Fortune 500 companies, and more than 6,000 campuses, businesses, and governments come to Coursera to access world-class learning—anytime, anywhere. All made possible by your passion to learn without limits and the efforts of 200+ leading universities and companies around the world.

Meet Wesley. Today, he has a great career working as an IT Support Technician at a healthcare call center. But just a few short years ago, he wasn’t sure he had the skills or the experience to compete for good jobs.  He’d enrolled in community college, but then left when he realized it wasn’t the right learning experience for him. He needed to find another way to start his career. He applied for an internship opportunity and was accepted. During that time, a career coach recommended Coursera.   That’s when he discovered he could learn IT skills from experts at Google. He was excited by the possibilities. He’d always been interested in computers and technology—maybe now, he could make it his career. “Coursera changed the way that I see, and how I learn things. It helped me break the barrier to a stable career.”  Today, he’s proud of the independence he’s achieved: “I have my own career. I live on my own. It really gives me a confidence boost to see how far I’ve come.” His colleagues at work describe him as a “superhero” because of the way he quickly and knowledgeably solves their IT problems.  It’s still early in his career journey, but Wesley already has a clear sense of what’s important: “For me, success is having a fulfilled life, and taking all the chances you can.”  Interested in exploring a career in IT like Wesley? Read this free career guide today: https://bit.ly/3mK2C5n

Meet Daniel. Today, he’s succeeding in an IT role that he loves—something he achieved after years of searching for the right career path. He appreciates the sense of possibility he feels now: “I can grow as high as I want. I can swim as far as I want and to any branch or division of IT.”  It wasn’t always an easy journey, and the way forward wasn’t always clear. Daniel folded clothes in a retail store, did door-to-door sales for a roofing company, and worked in a car factory.   He also spent years in restaurants. He sees a clear connection between his hospitality experience and his work today. They both involve helping people—something he finds very rewarding: “I love helping people with my skills, ” he says. Having the unique technical knowledge and training to succeed in his role helps Daniel feel valued at work.  After building new job skills with Google on Coursera, Daniel saw new doors open. Today, he loves his job, and he’s proud of his success: “Feeling like you earned it. It’s a beautiful thing.”  Discover new career possibilities with the Google IT Support Professional Certificate: https://bit.ly/3lcfJNd

#AI can do a lot, but can it help music composers? 🎶  With Juan's work––yes it can. See how:  “I created Komposair, a web app that generates music using artificial intelligence, using the skills I gained from completing the Deep Learning Specialization and DeepLearning.AI TensorFlow Developer Professional Certificate program.  My goal was to help musicians in the creative process. Sometimes, as a composer, I have a music idea (motif) that I would love to use in my music but I’m not sure how to further develop the motif. In those moments, I thought that AI could help the composer by providing different melodies that use the starting motif.  Music has a lot to do with patterns, and AI is great at recognizing patterns. In the future, I would like to expand Komposair to add more models based on different types of music (for instance, the last model I added is based on Chinese music).   I see the workflow like this: A composer has a motif → She goes to Komposair to generate ideas based on this motif → She selects one of the melodies given by Komposair and downloads it as a MIDI file → She now adds harmony, changes a little bit of the melody (if necessary) and when it's ready, she creates a music piece out of this.  I also created a Guided Project on Coursera based on this web app. I invite you to check it out!” - Juan P., Coursera Learner and Guided Projects Instructor  Wow! Amazing work, Juan 👏Thanks for sharing how you’re applying your skills to real-world projects.  Check out Juan’s Guided Project: https://bit.ly/2SZogaA

“During the two and a half years that I’ve been enrolled in the online Master of Computer and Information Technology program, I’ve balanced my part-time courses against a busy work schedule—first in parallel with my former role in international education, and later alongside five different software engineering internships. During this same time, I’ve lived in four countries and traveled across six more!  I’m proud of being an online student in computer science with a non-traditional background, and I think one of the greatest things about this program is the diversity of experiences of the student body. I didn’t come from a tech background. I earned my bachelor’s in biological sciences, and previously worked in international education. Today, I’m in an online degree program that is challenging and disrupting the ways we traditionally learn on-campus, and I’m proud of challenging conventions around how we learn, how we work and communicate — how we live. MCIT Online has given me the opportunity to find both personal fulfillment and professional success in disrupting these conventions and forging my own path.” – Angela Wen, current Penn MCIT Online Student  Learn more about the University of Pennsylvania's online Master of Computer and Information Technology degree: https://bit.ly/33JGy20   #WithoutLimits #LearnWithoutLimits

As Coursera goes public today, we want to mark this next chapter with a heartfelt thank you.  What started as an idea in 2012 has now evolved into a global community of 77 million learners. Over the years, we’ve been inspired by the stories you have shared—of second chances, new doors opening, and giving back to your communities with new-found skills.   As a public B Corp, we are committed to using our resources to pursue our vision of creating a world where anyone, anywhere has the power to transform their life through learning. Today and always, every member of Team Coursera, along with our partner community of 200+ university and industry educators, aspires to continue reducing barriers to world-class education so learners everywhere can collaborate, learn, and advance together.  Thank you for showing us how to learn without limits.

People who develop these skills on Coursera are in high demand. So what does a data analyst do every day? Take a peek into the life of a data analyst to see if it’s a good fit for you!  8AM - It’s another day full of exciting data problems to solve! Grab a cup of coffee and catch up on emails to get updated on the strategic focuses of your day.  9AM - Looks like someone at your organization has an urgent strategic question they want you to investigate. Collect data for your analysis by querying databases, gathering survey responses, and more.  11AM - Clean and prepare the data for analysis.  12PM - Create and test hypotheses by looking for insights in the data you’ve gathered.  1PM - Lunchtime! Take a break while your analyses run.  2PM - Now that you’ve gathered some actionable insights, create data visualizations to clearly communicate those findings to others.  4PM - Meet with stakeholders to share your findings and the data-driven reasons behind them.    5PM - Document and share your insights and next steps over email. The work you did today can have a real impact on your organization’s practices and policies! . . . Build your data analytics career with IBM’s Data Analyst Professional Certificate:  https://bit.ly/2YoXZlO

Meet Graça Machel--former Mozambique Minister for Education and Culture and overall philanthropic powerhouse. During her tenure, she worked towards implementing universal education for all Mozambicans.   ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ Thanks to her efforts, from 1975 to 1985, the number of students enrolled in primary and secondary schools rose from about 40% of all school-aged children to over 90% for males and 75% for females. When she left office, 1.5 million children were enrolled in school, compared to the 400,000 when she started, and she reduced the nation’s illiteracy rate by 72%.   ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ Through the Graça Machel Trust, this #LearningHero continues her lifelong advocacy for education and children’s rights.   ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ #WomensHistoryMonth

Eight years ago, she and Andrew Ng  launched Coursera, envisioning a world where high quality education is accessible to anyone, anywhere.  “Online education, then, can serve two goals. For students lucky enough to have access to great teachers, blended learning can mean even better outcomes at the same or lower cost. And for the millions here and abroad who lack access to good, in-person education, online learning can open doors that would otherwise remain closed.”  #WomensHistoryMonth

A strong advocate for women’s rights and education in Afghanistan, Jamila Afghani dedicates her career to expanding opportunities for women and girls.   During her time as a social worker in Afghan refugee camps in Pakistan, she volunteered to teach classes in which many women learned to read and write for the first time. Fueled by the impact she was making, she later founded the Noor Educational and Capacity Development Organization (NECDO), which has empowered and educated more than 50,000 women.   “If you educate one woman, you educate a whole family. It’s just like a candle – if you light one candle, that candle can light many others around it. That is how our societies will become more enlightened — in Afghanistan, and throughout the world.” - Jamila Afghani  #LearningHero #WomensHistoryMonth

#WomensHistoryMonth celebrates the history and achievements of women, past and present. This month, we’re celebrating the women around the world who are making education available and accessible to everyone. They are our #LearningHeroes.   We’re kicking it off with Nobel Peace Laureate Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, former president of #Liberia, and the first elected female head of state in Africa. During her presidency, she made education free and mandatory for all elementary school children. She also enacted a long-term Ministry of Education Operational Plan that focuses on the expansion and quality improvement of preschool and primary education.   “What factor has the power to transform individual lives, communities, nations and the world? The answer to this complex question is a simple one: education.” - Ellen Johnson Sirleaf

Today we’re celebrating the life and legacy of  Booker Taliaferro Washington, one of the most prominent African American leaders in the U.S. and influential black educators of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.   Washington fought for economic progress, educational opportunity, and justice in the courts for African Americans during a time of segregation, Jim Crow Laws, and heightened racial tensions. Despite the immense difficulty of the post-Reconstruction era, he and his contemporaries worked tirelessly to elevate, educate, and create economic opportunities for the black community.   He was also an author, orator, and advisor to multiple presidents of the United States including Presidents Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft. Not only was Washington a key proponent of African- American businesses and one of the founders of the National Negro Business League, he also founded what became known as Tuskegee University in 1881 which went on to become one of the leading schools in the United States.   Let’s keep the celebration going: who are your African American learning heroes? Let us know in the comments below👇🏾  #BlackHistoryMonth #BookerTWashington #LearningHero

We’d like to give a big shout out to #LearningHero Kimberly Bryant, an electrical engineer who founded Black Girls CODE.   According to a Kapor Center study, women of color earn less than 10% of bachelor’s degrees in computing, and black women make up less than 0.5% of leadership roles in tech. Black Girls Code is changing and improving these percentages for the better.  In 2013, Bryant was honored as a White House Champion of Change for Tech Inclusion, which recognizes “leaders who have done extraordinary work to connect kids from underrepresented and underserved communities to tech skills and opportunities.” That same year, Business Insider featured her as one of the 25 Most Influential African-Americans In Technology. Bryant was also awarded the Pahara-Aspen Education Fellowship, an organization which “seeks to strengthen and sustain diverse, high potential leaders who are reimagining public education.”  #BlackHistoryMonth

Fannie C. Williams pioneered advancements in education and the public school system in the South. This #LearningHero instituted kindergarten and standardized testing for students before Louisiana required it, and she served as president of the National Association of Teachers in Colored Schools. In 1946, Dillard University opened the Fannie C. Williams Hall to honor her contributions to education.  As a principal, she also regularly advocated for the betterment and professional development of her students and staff, many of whom went on to lead other educational institutions across the country.   #BlackHistoryMonth

In honor of #BlackHistoryMonth, we’re celebrating African American learning heroes from past to present. These are some of the many men and women who helped create a better world by advancing learning.   Today we’re celebrating the life and legacy of literary hero, professor, and editor Toni Morrison. When this Nobel Laureate and Pulitzer Prize winning author wasn’t working on her next great novel, she was building the next generation of writers through teaching.   She began her teaching career in 1957 as an English professor at Howard University. She then went on to teach English at two State University of New York campuses and at Rutgers University. In 1989, Morrison continued her academic career at Princeton University where she established a workshop for creative professionals known as the Princeton Atelier––a program which pairs artists from different disciplines, like writers and dancers, to collaborate and create new work in a semester-long course.    Photo Source: Timothy Greenfield-Sanders  #LearningHero #Literature #ToniMorrison

A huge shout-out to Liz, a Data Scientist #LearningFrom the United Kingdom who submitted this learning tip in the Coursera Community. . . . “Use the Feynman learning technique:  1. Pick a topic you want to understand and start studying it. Write down everything you know about the topic on a notebook page, and add to that page every time you learn something new about it.  2. Pretend to teach your topic to a classroom. Make sure you're able to explain the topic in simple terms.  3. Go back to the books when you get stuck. The gaps in your knowledge should be obvious. Revisit problem areas until you can explain the topic fully.  4. Simplify and use analogies. Repeat the process while simplifying your language and connecting facts with analogies to help strengthen your understanding.”   Find more study tips from learners in the Coursera Community: https://bit.ly/2wIj2Sq

Meet Christina J. from Texas! In her downtime, she tinkers with computers to help visually impaired users access the internet. After earning her certificate, Christina took her knowledge and used it to help others at a non-profit in Richardson, TX: Computers for the Blind. Skill you'll need in #2019: Artificial Intelligence 🤖  Today, 72% of CEOs regard AI competencies as the most important asset of a company. In turn, the demand for talent with advanced AI skills like machine learning and deep learning continues to increase. But as more engineers gain this technical knowledge, a new skills gap is forming. Now, we’re seeing demand from non-technical company leaders across industries to understand how to they can align their long-term business strategies with today’s AI capabilities. This foundational knowledge will only become more important to executives next year, as AI continues to dominate business plans around the globe. We predict Andrew’s latest, AI for Everyone, designed with this challenge top of mind, will join deep technical AI knowledge on next year’s list. Learn more: https://buff.ly/2Qrqq0I  #AI

Water is essential to sustaining life, but current water and sanitation conditions lead to over 2 million deaths annually due to water-related diseases.  Subsequently, there are millions of dollars spent in avoidable health care expenditures, and billions of hours spent carrying water from sources outside the home. The world's population is at seven billion people, and is pacing to swell to nine billion by 2050.   A growing population puts pressure on our most important resource: WATER. This strains food, water and energy supplies, and threatens biodiversity.   Join one of two new water-centric courses launching today!

"Yesterday was a very emotional day for a lot of us at Coursera. We got to meet Dan Bergmann, an autistic student who completed over 7 college level courses on Coursera, in-person. Dan was in special education all his life because he had limited speaking vocabulary. But on the Coursera platform, he can watch lectures at his own pace and communicate through typing at a college level. As a result, a learner who was placed in the remedial learning track has taken and excelled at advanced level poetry and history courses...AND has been invited by a University of Pennsylvania professor to be a Community Teaching Assistant. We are incredibly motivated by Dan so much so that we painted him on one of our conference room walls.   It was priceless for us to see his giddy reaction when he saw his own portrait. Dan, you make us as a company (and as individuals) better through the example you set in love for learning and perseverance.   This is why I work at Coursera."   Read Daniel's story: http://bit.ly/1tv6lRU

Enhance your impact this Earth Day by educating yourself in the Earth Sciences.  Join one of dozens of courses! http://ow.ly/w2H5q  Facts:  > Land: Covering less than 2% of the Earth's surface area, rainforests are home to 50% of the Earth's plants and animals. At the current rate of tropical forest loss, 5–10% of rainforest species will be lost per decade.  > Sea: Coral reefs are critical to maintain ocean's entire ecosystem. As more carbon dioxide enters the ocean from practices like overfishing, fishing using cyanide and dynamite, etc. 75% of remaining coral reefs are currently threatened, and many have already been lost.  > Air: Giant livestock farms (aka "Factory Farms) contribute to the release of concentrated amounts of toxic gases into the air such as ammonia and hydrogen sulfide, which can travel for hundreds of miles. They also release methane into the air (a greenhouse gas), which causes a "rotten egg" smell.   Easy ways you can help:    > Reduce paper usage: tote reusable grocery bags, make used envelopes scrap paper, craft homemade cards from old magazines, get off the mailing lists of catalogs, etc.  > Eat fish and meats consciously and from sustainable sources. Better yet, consider reducing your intake of animal products entirely!    Share your tips!

Right: This month we collaged ~1,500 photos of Courserians on a wall in our office. Thomas Jefferson acted as the spokesman for a revolutionary generation of Americans who created a new nation based on radical ideas.  His influence on governments and societies continue to be powerfully felt nearly two centuries after his death, both in the U.S. and around the world.  Enroll in this fascinating "Age of Jefferson" course from University of Virginia and Monticello, led by renowned Thomas Jefferson scholar Peter S. Onuf: http://ow.ly/tyeyr

Today we're excited to announce a partnership with the Carlos Slim Foundation to expand learning opportunities in Latin America and for Spanish speakers anywhere.   Our shared goal is to support career development and employment, which we will do by translating and creating course content in high demand fields like computer science, teacher PD and healthcare, as well as opening up physical locations where people can access online courses and in-person support.   Read more about our partnership here: http://bit.ly/MhJOHt

Due to U.S. export sanctions, we recently had to restrict access to students in Iran, Cuba, Sudan and, temporarily, Syria. Leiden University is offering a small private Masters-level online course on Sharia Law in the West. Students will be a mix of on-campus graduate students at Leiden and global students who apply to join. This will be an intensive, 14 week course with active participation of 10-20 hours per week.   Interested in applying to join? View how to apply to take the course here: http://hum.leiden.edu/students/agenda/online-ma-course-sharia-in-the-west.html   This course will be limited to a select number of participants with admission based on application. The deadline to apply is January 20th. The course is free, and you will not receive university credit.

Courserians and friends, we are excited to announce that our official #Coursera iPhone App has launched today!!  Download it here: http://bit.ly/1bUfJZA and happy learning-on-the-go! For Android users, our team is working on that app next :)!

5 Tips from Duke University on being a successful student in a MOOC:  1. Decide what you want to learn 2. Set time aside each week to watch lectures 3. Ask questions on forums 4. One of Coursera's all-time most popular courses is from Duke University called "Think Again: How to Reason and Argue". Our co-founder Daphne Koller has just joined the Global Learning Council, newly established by Carnegie Mellon University to bring together edtech leaders to develop standards, identify best practices and commit to openness for better learning outcomes - http://www.cmu.edu/news/stories/archives/2013/november/nov11_simoninitiative.html

By 2020, depressive disorder will likely be the most important cause of disease burden globally. This new course from Johns Hopkins University sheds light on Depression from a public health perspective. Class starts this week: http://bit.ly/HJy5PS.  Questions addressed in course are:  -What is depression and what is depressive disorder? -How common is depressive disorder? -What are crosscultural variation in depression and depressive disorder?  -What is the research being done on prevention of depression? -What is the system of care for psychiatric disorders and depression?

What is a nanometer?  For reference,  the diameter of a tennis ball is 100,000,000 nanometers long -- think about that scale! Nanotechnology is an exciting research area that spans disciplines from electrical engineering to biology.  It has created many medical breakthroughs.  Learn about them in only 4 weeks from Rice University. Class starts 11/11: http://bit.ly/1cxS1mZ

Hi everyone!  Today, Coursera announcing partnerships with U.S. Department of State and 7 other organizations including Digital October Center to launch 30 physical Learning Hubs in over 20 countries across 5 continents!  Learning Hubs is a global initiative in community building + blended learning through establishing physical networks of space, facilitators and students worldwide! http://bit.ly/1coj2oB    We believe this is an important step in reducing geographic and connectivity barriers to bring us one step closer to making education a basic human right.

Professor Ping-Cheng (Benson) Yeh of National Taiwan University is the first professor to create a multiplayer social gaming platform for his course, Probability, which is now in session. Learn more about what professors and students can do with PaGamO in their courses!  http://bit.ly/16pljfs

Did you know that over 150,000 students have enrolled in Co-Founder Andrew Ng's Machine Learning course?  The course is starting again this week -- don't miss out on one of the most popular classes on coursera, ever.  http://bit.ly/135Bg8X      More about Professor Ng's course: Machine learning is the science of getting computers to act without being explicitly programmed. In the past decade, machine learning has given us self-driving cars, practical speech recognition, effective web search, and a vastly improved understanding of the human genome.

Interested in Epidemics?  Like to play games?  You HAVE to check out this new course from Penn State called "Epidemics - the Dynamics of Infectious Diseases". How can we define conditions that lead to war and peace? When do you think wars are necessary? – These are open-ended questions that allow possibilities of many different answers. This week, University of Tokyo launched “Conditions of War and Peace”, a course taught by Kiichi Fujiwara that discusses these topics in depth. Sign up here: https://www.coursera.org/course/warandpeace

Attention Secondary/College students: Earn a College Credit Recommendation from ACE CREDIT with Pre-Calculus from UC Irvine (class starts 10/7)!  To earn credit recommendation, follow these 4 steps: http://bit.ly/18Io5zi  1 Check with your school to see if they accept ACE CREDIT College Credit Recommendations (Over 2,000 schools will consider them!) 2. Then, enroll in Pre-Calculus. 3. Next, be sure to register for Signature Track by the end of the third week of the course 4. Finally, at the end of the course, schedule your online proctored Credit Recommendation exam.

Popular course from Princeton University:   Statistics One is a comprehensive yet friendly introduction to the fundamental principles of statistics.  It starts on 9/22: https://www.coursera.org/course/stats1     Comprehensive means that this course provides a solid foundation for students planning to pursue more advanced courses in statistics. Friendly means exactly that. The course assumes very little background knowledge in statistics and introduces new concepts with several fun and easy to understand examples.

Today is “Flip Your Classroom Day” and a great reason to think about how our approach to learning can change to help all students reach their full potential.    Teachers: excited to flip your classroom?  Already do? Don’t know what flipping your classroom is?  Well, we have a challenge for all of you!  Jump into the deep end, flip your classroom, and then keep swimming even deeper into personalized education.  How do you do that?  Sign up today for our MOOC, “Blended Learning: Personalizing Education for Students” to find out!  It launches on October 15th. http://bit.ly/1dNtMAA  See you then!

Nuevo Curso de Tecnológico de Monterrey: Conceptos y herramientas para la física universitaria: Todo lo que necesitas saber para tener éxito en tus cursos de física!  Iniciamos el 23 de septiembre de 2013. Inscríbete aquí: http://bit.ly/17a5lYG    El curso te proveerá de herramientas matemáticas útiles para el éxito en tus cursos universitarios de física. Se cubrirán temas conceptuales y procedimentales relativos a la Física y se desarrollan capacidades de aplicarlos en tu vida profesional.    Aprenderás:  A aplicar el cálculo diferencial e integral para interpretar y modelar la cinemática de una partícula en una dimensión  El manejo de cantidades físicas vectoriales en forma gráfica y analítica en dos y tres dimensiones  A usar herramientas de código libre (Geogebra, Tracker) para la solución de problemas

Co-Founder Daphne Koller wrote an article for Wealthfront today that urges to anyone who wants to advance their career to look into the importance MOOCs can have in helping them get ahead in their field: http://bit.ly/18yf6Qi.   "MOOCs open up many additional paths for advancement. Think of the potential for an engineer who takes a class in machine learning to gain a greater understanding of what can be automated. On the flip side: a product manager or marketing director who learns to code could communicate better with engineers, gaining the credibility needed to push an organization forward."

Meet Minjeong, everyone!  She is a product designer at #Coursera. She loves to design, do handstands and is here to tell you about one of her favorite courses: Microeconomics Principles, which starts again on August 26th. Sign up: http://bit.ly/12FlftE!   "I recommend Dr. José J. Vázquez-Cognet's course for anyone who wants to get an introduction to #economics. It steps through basic models that explain the relationships between supply, demand and cost in a market. Dr. Vázquez-Cognet spends much of his lecture time deftly hand-drawing curves and explaining models, but the best part is where he relates the abstract concepts to local businesses that he personally visits.  Through this course, you will be able to relate microeconomics theories with the markets you see around you.   Also, if you're curious about the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign or the surrounding neighborbood, this course will give you a glimpse of what it's like to be there!"  To Learn more, http://bit.ly/12FlftE.  Thanks for your recommendation, Minjeong!

How can a younger student maximize their #Coursera experience?  Here are 3 tips from one of our youngest students, Khadija Niazi:  1. Don't be shy, try out something you know nothing about 2. Manage your time with tools and use forums for help 3. Watch lectures with your family, its fun!  Read the full tips here: http://bit.ly/147xxwy

How can we build a Global Classroom?  Daphne Koller, Coursera's Co-Founder shares the following thoughts in a self-authored CNN article published today:   "To me, achieving a global classroom means using education to erase barriers between people of different cultures and backgrounds; it means giving people the opportunity to learn without the limits imposed by physical or socio-economic circumstances; and it means giving schools and instructors around the world the ability to transcend boundaries to bring high-quality education to their students."    http://bit.ly/11RugKO

Hi Courserians, meet Bipin, one of our software engineers! He loves building new things, taking art classes, boxing & telling you about his new favorite course: Startup Engineering, which starts on June 17th (http://bit.ly/18vS800)!  "I'm an engineer here at Coursera, and I highly recommend Dr. Balaji Srinivasan and Professor Vijay Pande's upcoming Startup Engineering course. The course surveys successful entrepreneurs for some fascinating insights, and teaches you the skills you'll need to build a startup from the ground up - from technical implementation through recruiting, marketing, and funding.  It was taught at Stanford University from January to March this year. Some of the students from that offering have already raised venture capital and are starting their own companies. If startups interest you, you should definitely check this class out!" -Bipin

Coursera's first Teacher Professional Development course launches in July. In a recent Forbes article, our partner the New Teacher Center discusses importance of scaling up resources for teachers with MOOCS:  "With an estimated demand for 350,000 new teachers [in the US alone] each year for the next five years, scaling support for them is of critical importance. We owe it to our students to ensure they have great teachers at the front of their classrooms, regardless of a teacher’s years of experience, and regardless of a student’s zip code."  http://onforb.es/ZG2gx9

Jonathan Haber shares with us his 3 tips on how to effectively do quizzes, homework & assignments on Coursera in a 2 minute video.  http://bit.ly/16Y7IAY  Preview Tip: Take a day between lectures and taking a quiz to maximize what you store in long vs. short term memory.  Learn more by clicking on the link above!    PS - Did you know that Jonathan is close to completing 16 of the 32 courses he has set out to do this year?  Way to go!

The European Union is an example of a supranational legal order to which 27 Member States have transferred sovereign rights. How did the EU come about? What impact does the EU have?  Whether you're a student, lawyer, entrepreneur or simply interested in the EU, join us in The Law of the European Union: An Introduction!  This course, beginning on 6/10, is taught by: Universiteit Leiden / Leiden University. http://bit.ly/13QXcFI

As you know, Coursera takes Friday dress-up *very* seriously.  Yesterday, we decided to go "formal".  We wanted to share this spontaneous photoshoot with you.  Thanks for all your support to motivate us to do great work and have fun while we're at it!

University of Pittsburgh is offering a course called "A Look at Nuclear Science and Technology".  It will focus on the theory, design and operation of commercial nuclear power reactors. The course will also touch on issues regarding nuclear power generation including: the nuclear fuel cycle, the economics of nuclear power, and nuclear non-proliferation.  http://bit.ly/1b9kSrc  Course starts on 6/10!

The world is ageing – people are older and societies are facing hard realities. What are we to make our lives in this time of global ageing? In six weeks, this University of Pennsylvania course analyzes critical questions about age and ageing around the world.http://bit.ly/ZMZetf  Course started this week, sign up now!

Coursera is delighted to announce that The University of Chicago joins our consortium of 80 national and international education partners!  http://bit.ly/10ObloB  The University of Chicago will offer an initial two courses on Coursera’s platform, with plans to expand their offerings based on faculty interest. The following courses, taught by renowned professors in their fields, will build out Coursera’s catalog in the areas of science and business.  We'll let you know when they are available.  Here is a preview of what to expect:  -Global Warming, taught by David Archer: Professor in Geophysical Sciences and a fellow of the American Geophysical Union. This course is one of the University of Chicago’s most popular, and will introduce students to theories, views and studies around global warming, climate change and human involvement.   -Asset Pricing Theory, taught by John Cochrane: AQR Capital Management Distinguished Service Professor of Finance at the Booth School of Business. This advanced course, designed for doctoral students in economics and finance, will now be available to anyone around the world working within the finance industry who wishes to continue their studies and learn from one of the top experts in asset pricing.

Roya Mahboob (who is on Time Magazine's 100 most Influential people list) came with her sister to visit Coursera recently. Roya is one of the only Female CEOs in Afghanistan and serves as a symbol of hope in bringing gender equality to females in a country where many women still work from home. We are honored to have hosted your visit, Roya!  http://time100.time.com/2013/04/18/time-100/slide/roya-mahboob/

A typical day at work....

Today is a big day: Coursera turns 1!  As our birthday wish, we want you to share your favorite course recommendation with the world through pictures.  We hope to make a 1st birthday Courserians mural at Coursera HQ with your pictures!  To Participate:  1. Go to: http://bit.ly/15nlBXC 2. Print and cut out shape 3. Write in your favorite course 4. Take a picture of yourself (smile, be silly!) 5. Upload it to your FB wall and tag @Coursera!  [the picture here is an example of what you can submit!]  We'll take it and print these pictures into a mural and share the final product with you!  Thank you for being an important part of this vibrant learning community of 3.2 million people all on a quest to create an ecosystem where education is a human right and learning has no limits!

8-time Grammy award winning Berklee College of Music professor Gary Burton's much anticipated Introduction to Improvisation course begins next Monday, 4/22!  We here at Coursera HQ are very excited to take it -- see you there! http://bit.ly/XEo2jZ
Our thoughts go out to Courserians in Boston today.  Find out if you can get answers or give help with Google's Person Finder service: http://bit.ly/ZmyrBh

Learn fascinating studies about the brain, consciousness and memory systems!   University of Toronto's Introduction to Psychology course starts on May 6th and the course is 8 weeks long. Sign up here: http://bit.ly/ZsFvsZ  [Photo Credit: http://0.tqn.com/d/psychology/1/0/K/6/human-brain.png]
We are curious: Courserians, where do you usually prefer to take Coursera Courses?

Healthy eating starts with healthy cooking.  Maya Adam, M.D. of Stanford University teaches principles behind healthy cooking.  This is a great course for Courserians with interest in medicine, child health, psychology or nutrition.  Enroll here: http://bit.ly/10XJn6U.  Course starts on May 6th so get your pots and pans ready!

Did you know that the average Courserian enrolls in 2-3 courses at the same time?  To help you stay organized with deadlines for courses, our engineering team has created a helpful new feature called Deadlines Calendars! Learn how to use it: http://bit.ly/10UjEuC
Many of you have been asking to see pictures from the Coursera Partners' Conference.  Without further ado, here are some photos taken by our engineer, Frank Chen!  http://on.fb.me/10JQ2Bc

The Beatles are coming--Elvis, Mick, Dylan and the Ronettes too!  University of Rochester's "History of Rock Part 1" hits Coursera on May 13th!  Sign up and get ready to rock out:  http://bit.ly/12AVSu1  [picture credits: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Beatles]

We had a fantastic day at University of Pennsylvania hosting the inaugural Coursera Partners' Conference!  Check out the twittersphere for updates and pictures: http://bit.ly/10BUbZn.  Notice any familiar faces in this picture?  You may if you have taken #Modpo, #Gamification13 or #insidetheinternet! #CourseraConfAtPenn

The world is full of data.  Learn methods to make sense of it all with University of Toronto's statistics course.  This course can help you become more analytical in school, your job, or  how you approach everyday information!  Class just started this week! Join in: http://bit.ly/10z9xLD

We are so thrilled to introduce to you one of the most highly anticipated courses on Coursera, taught by world-renowned anthropologist, Phineas Dunne. Be one of the first students to sign up: http://bit.ly/YPz96z!  First 1000 students may be chosen to participate in a real life research project with the Professor!
How much can a person learn from various MOOC platforms in 12 months?  One Courserian is doing an experiment to find out!  Hear more about the project here: http://bit.ly/164Ros3

Exciting news!  The inaugural Coursera Partners’ Conference (http://conference.coursera.org/) will be held April 5-6, 2013 at the University of Pennsylvania. It brings together university officials, faculty members, instructional program managers, and teaching support staff from across our partner schools and guest institutions for two days of lively discussion about MOOCs, online pedagogies, and emerging trends in higher education. The conference aims to provide an opportunity for members of the Coursera community to learn from each other and share their experiences in designing, creating, and delivering MOOCs, and to discuss the rapidly transforming landscape in higher education.    Want to give a shoutout to a professor? We'll share it with them at the conference: http://bit.ly/11RQ0fv

Why are some apps easier to use than others?  Understanding how humans interact with interfaces can make all the difference.  Design technologies that bring people joy, rather than frustration!  http://bit.ly/13xlYPr  The 3rd offering of Stanford University's #HCI course starts this Sunday, March 31st.  This course is a Coursera staff favorite!

Interested in majoring in neuroscience?  Just curious about how your brain works? In 9 lectures, learn everything from the cellular composition of the brain to new research on consciousness and music: http://bit.ly/10MoqO0!  Class starts this Sunday, March 31st.

Ever wonder why games like Angry Birds, Words With Friends and Call of Duty: Black Ops are so popular?  Learn all about the concept of Gamification from University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business. Class begins April 1st, 2013 and is 6 weeks long! http://bit.ly/X6Y49C

Did you know Coursera has a new front page?  You can now directly search for stuff you want to learn about when you go to www.coursera.org/welcome.  Learn more from our engineering team and try it out! http://bit.ly/Y8yYql

We love the stories you're sharing with us, everyone! Here is a great one we got today: see how Sharon Watkins of Ohio, USA used a Coursera Business course to help people in her community improve their careers: http://bit.ly/10oWGPj

Today, the Coursera community grew to 3,000,000 users!  It has been an exciting 11 months and we couldn't be where we are today without you. A bill is under consideration in the Senate that would force California’s public colleges to give credit for online courses. This is an important first step to solving a critical need and there is a lot more to be done. Read more: http://bit.ly/10OZjML

Nearly everyone has heard of him—he is the most recognizable scientist of all time, he was chosen as ‘Person of the Century’ by Time magazine.  Who is he?  Einstein, of course! Daphne Koller, Coursera's Co-Founder writes a message to emphasize the importance of #womensday and women's education:      "We are proud to have a strong and growing women presence, actively contributing to their communities, bringing positive change in society through education. Today, we celebrate efforts made by every person, organization, and group in the world to ensure the future for women is bright, equal, safe and rewarding. Coursera strongly believes in creating an intellectually stimulating, healthy and safe learning environment for each and every student. Inside Higher Ed wrote an article today on leading MOOCs and the progress we're making toward ensuring student health and safety in the online space.  It is an important topic that everyone should, as members of this community, be aware of.  Read about it here:  bit.ly/W4ry6j

A few of us here at Coursera have been chatting about what it means to be a "Courserian".  We think the term describes someone who has a curiosity to learn and is empowered to do good for their community as a result.  We'd really like to hear your definition to help us form a community identity! Tell us, what does being a Courserian mean to you?

What is self knowledge and why does it matter?  University of Virginia's course "Know Thy Self" explores this topic and is one of Coursera's most popularly enrolled classes this month.  Class starts tomorrow, March 4th, 2013.  https://www.coursera.org/course/knowthyself

Bonjour Courserians!  We're stoked to tell you about our first course in a foreign language:  Analyse Numérique pour Ingénieurs (Numerical Analysis for Engineers)! Tamar Lewin from the NYTimes writes about her experience taking "Listening to World Music" with Professor Carol Muller from UPenn.   "Tuvan throat singing was never in my repertoire. I had never heard of Tuva, a small Russian republic north of Mongolia. And until the third week of  “Listening to World Music,” a free online course taught by a University of Pennsylvania professor, I did not know that the human throat was capable of producing two notes simultaneously...."   http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/20/education/online-course-opens-minds-to-world-music.html?_r=0

Introduction to Astronomy from Professor Ronen Plesser at Duke University starts next week on November 27th!   "We will then embark on a journey, starting here on Earth and progressing outward, to study the Solar system, the Milky Way galaxy, and the wonderful and strange objects we observe in deep space, such as black holes, quasars, and supernovae.  We will end with some discussion of what scientists know today about the universe as a whole.  Along the way we will introduce some of the methods, theoretical and experimental, that have been used to understand all of this, from Newton's laws, through our understanding of light and matter, to Einstein's theory of relativity, and from Galileo's telescope to WMAP." Prof. Plesser    https://www.coursera.org/course/introastro

"But the deals Coursera announced Tuesday may well prove to be an inflection point for online education, a sector that has traditionally been dominated by for-profit colleges known mostly for their noxious recruitment practices and poor results. That's because the new partnerships represent an embrace of web-based learning from across the top tier of U.S. universities. And where the elite colleges go, so goes the rest of academia." http://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2012/07/the-single-most-important-experiment-in-higher-education/259953/
